{{Infobox university |name = King's College London |latin_name = |image_name = KCL Coat of arms1.png |image_size = 140px |caption = [[Coat of arms|Arms]] of King's College London |motto = Sancte et Sapienter |mottoeng = With Holiness and Wisdom |established = 1829 |type = [[public university|Public]] |endowment = Â£115.23 million{{cite web|url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/content/1/c6/02/39/08/financialstatements2010.pdf|title=Financial Statements for the year to 31 July 2010|accessdate=26 January 2011|publisher=King's College London}} |staff = |chancellor = [[HRH]] [[Anne, Princess Royal|The Princess Royal]] ([[University of London]]) |principal = [[Rick Trainor|Prof Sir Rick Trainor]]{{cite web|url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/about/structure/principal/trainor.html|title=Principal of King's College London â Professor Rick Trainor|year=2009|accessdate=2009-03-05}} |head_label = Chairman of the Council |head = [[Charles Wellesley, Marquess of Douro|Charles Wellesley, 10th Duke of Ciudad Rodrigo]]{{cite web|url=https://www.kcl.ac.uk/content/1/c4/29/75/Councilmembership2008-9.pdf|title=King's College London Council membership 2008/09|year=2008|accessdate=2009-03-05}} |students = 18,630 |undergrad = 12,320 |postgrad = 6,310 |doctoral = |city = London |country = United Kingdom |coor = {{coord|51|30|43.00|N|0|06|58.00|W|display=inline,title|type:edu}} |campus = Urban |free_label = Visitor |free = [[Archbishop of Canterbury|The Archbishop of Canterbury]] ''[[ex officio]]''{{cite web| url = http://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld/ldreg/reg06.htm| title =The Archbishop of Canterbury â Register of Lords' interests | accessdate = 2007-08-15 | publisher=[[House of Lords]]}} |mascot = [[King's College London Students' Union#Mascot|Reggie the Lion]] |affiliations = [[University of London]]
[[Russell Group]]
[[Golden Triangle (UK universities)|Golden Triangle]]
[[European University Association|EUA]]
[[Association of Commonwealth Universities|ACU]] |footnotes = |newsletter = Comment |colours=
                     
|website = [http://www.kcl.ac.uk/ kcl.ac.uk] |logo = [[Image:Kcl-logo.svg|210px]] }} '''King's College London''' (informally '''King's''' or '''KCL''') is a [[public university|public]] [[research university]] located in London, United Kingdom and a [[constituent college]] of the federal [[University of London]]. King's has a claim to being the [[Third oldest university in England debate|third oldest university in England]], having been founded by [[George IV of the United Kingdom|King George IV]] and the [[Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington|Duke of Wellington]] in 1829, and having received its [[royal charter]] in 1836.{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/education/sunday_times_university_guide/article4767634.ece|title=Profile: Durham University|work=The Sunday Times |location=London | date=2010-12-09 | accessdate=15 September 2010}}[http://www.independent.co.uk/student/into-university/az-uni-colleges/ucl-university-college-london-459098.html Reference to UCL as third oldest university in England.] In 1836 King's became one of the two founding colleges of the University of London.{{cite web|url=https://kcl.ac.uk/about/|title=About King's College London=King's College London|year=2006|accessdate=2008-01-16}}{{cite web|url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/college/policyzone/attachments/CharterStatutes.pdf|format=PDF|title=Royal Charter of King's College London=King's College London|year=2006|accessdate=2008-01-16 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080229031745/http://www.kcl.ac.uk/college/policyzone/attachments/CharterStatutes.pdf |archivedate = 2008-02-29}} King's is arranged into [[King's College London#Schools|nine Schools of Study]], spread across four [[Thames]]-side [[King's College London#Campuses|campuses]] in [[Central London]] and one in [[Denmark Hill]], [[South London]].{{cite web|url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/about/campuses/|title=King's College London: Campuses=King's College London|year=2006|accessdate=2008-01-16}} It is one of the largest centres for graduate and post-graduate medical teaching and biomedical research in Europe; it is home to six [[Medical Research Council (UK)#Institutes, Centres and Units|Medical Research Council centres]], the most of any British university,{{cite web|url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/research/mrc.html|title=Medical Research Council centres|year=2009|accessdate=2009-07-01}} and is a founding member of the [[King's Health Partners]] [[academic health sciences centre]]. King's has around 18,600 full-time students and 5,030 staff and had a total income of Â£508 million in 2009/10, of which Â£144 million was from research grants and contracts. There are currently 10 Nobel Prize laureates amongst King's alumni and current and former faculty.{{cite web|url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/newsevents/news/newsrecords/2010/oct/TenthNobelPrizeWinner.aspx|title=Tenth Nobel Prize Winner|accessdate=27 October 2010|publisher=King's College London}} King's is ranked 63rd in the world (and 16th in Europe) in the 2010 ''[[Academic Ranking of World Universities]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.arwu.org/ARWU2010.jsp|title=Top 100|accessdate=1 October 2010|publisher=Academic Ranking of World Universities â 2010}} 21st in the world (and 6th in Europe) in the 2010 ''[[QS World University Rankings]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.topuniversities.com/university-rankings/world-university-rankings/2010/results|title=QS World University Rankings Results 2010|accessdate=1 October 2010|publisher=QS Quacquarelli Symonds Limited}} and 77th in the world (and 15th in Europe) in the 2010 ''[[Times Higher Education World University Rankings]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/world-university-rankings/2010-2011/top-200.html|title=Top 200|accessdate=1 October 2010|publisher=Times Higher Education}} In September 2010, ''[[The Sunday Times]]'' selected King's as its "University of the Year".{{cite news| url=http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/University_Guide |work=The Sunday Times |location=London | accessdate=15 September 2010}} King's is a member of the [[Association of Commonwealth Universities]], the [[European University Association]], the [[Russell Group]] and [[Universities UK]]. It forms part of the [[Golden Triangle (UK universities)|'Golden Triangle']] of British universities.{{cite news|url=http://www.nature.com/naturejobs/2005/050707/full/nj7047-144a.html| title=Golden opportunities|accessdate=19 October 2010|publisher=Nature| date=6 July 2005}} {{TOC limit|limit=3}} == History == [[Image:Maughanclocktower.JPG|[[The Maughan Library]] on Chancery Lane is the College's main library|thumb|left|167px]] King's, so named to indicate the patronage of [[George IV of the United Kingdom|King George IV]], was founded in 1829 in response to the founding of "London University", latterly known as [[University College London]], in 1826.{{cite web|url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/about/history/found.html|title=Foundation of the College=King's College London|year=2005|accessdate=2008-01-16}} [[University College London|UCL]] was founded, with the backing of Jews, [[Utilitarians]] and [[Anglicanism|non-Anglican Christians]], as a secular institution, intended to educate "the youth of our middling rich people between the ages of 15 or 16 and 20 or later".{{Cite journal | first = F.J.C. | last = Hearnshaw | title = The Centenary History of King's College, London, 1828â1928 | publisher=Harrap | year = 1929 | page = 38}} The need for such an institution was a result of the religious nature of the Universities of Oxford and Cambridge, which then educated solely the sons of [[upper class|wealthy]] [[Anglicans]].{{cite web|last = Banerjee, PhD.|first = Jacqueline|title = The University of London: The Founding Colleges|url=http://www.victorianweb.org/history/education/ulondon/2.html|accessdate = 2007-05-26}} The foundation of [[University College London|UCL]] met with the disapproval of [[the establishment]], indeed, "the storms of opposition which raged around it threatened to crush every spark of vital energy which remained".{{cite book | last = MacIlwraith | first = W. | title = The Life and Writings of George Grote: An Essay | publisher=Barford & Newitt | year = 1884 | page = 32}} The Revd Dr George D'Oyly, rector of [[Lambeth]] and governor of [[Wilson's School]] in [[Camberwell]], opposing the secular nature of the college, published an open letter proposing the formation of a competing institution. This would be of a religious, and more particularly [[Anglican]], nature, one which would instil, "the services of religion performed as directed in our National Church". This prompted [[Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington]], the then Prime Minister to chair a public meeting which launched King's on 21 June 1828. His simultaneous support for the Anglican college and the [[Roman Catholic Relief Act]], which was to lead to the granting of almost full civil rights to Catholics, was challenged by [[George Finch-Hatton, 10th Earl of Winchilsea]] in early 1829. The result was a [[duel]] in [[Battersea Park|Battersea Fields]] on 21 March that year. Deliberately off-target shots were fired by both and neither was hurt.{{cite web |url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/college/history/found.html |title=Foundation of the College |work=King's College London â History of the College |accessdate=2006-11-20}} "Duel Day" is still celebrated on the first Thursday after 21 March every year, marked by various events throughout the College.{{cite web|url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/news/news_details.php?news_id=539&year=2007|title=Alumni celebrate Duel Day=King's College London|year=2007|accessdate=2008-01-23}} [[Image:Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington by Robert Home.jpg|[[Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington]] fought a [[duel]] against the [[George Finch-Hatton, 10th Earl of Winchilsea|Earl of Winchilsea]]in 1829 over the Duke's support for the rights of Irish Catholics, and the independence of the newly-established King's|thumb|150px|right]] King's opened in 1831, very much in a similar academic guise to Oxford. Despite the intentions of its founders and the chapel at the heart of its buildings, the initial prospectus permitted, "nonconformists of all sorts to enter the college freely".{{Cite journal | first = F.J.C. | last = Hearnshaw | title = The Centenary History of King's College, London, 1828â1928 | publisher=Harrap | year = 1929 | page = 80}} [[Chemistry]], [[English literature]] and Commerce were among the subjects offered. At this time, neither King's, nor "London University" had the ability to confer degrees, a particular problem for medical students who wished to practise. Amending this situation was aided by the appointment of [[Henry Brougham, 1st Baron Brougham and Vaux]] as [[Lord Chancellor]], who was chairman of the governors of "London University". In this position he automatically became a governor of King's. In the understanding that the [[UK government|government]] was unlikely to grant degree-awarding powers on two institutions in London, negotiations led to the colleges federating as the "[[University of London]]" in 1836, "London University" thus being changed to University College. King's professors played a part in scientific and social advances of the nineteenth century, through extending higher education to women, [[working class|the working class]], and by offering evening classes. One of the most famous pieces of scientific research performed at King's was the work by [[Maurice Wilkins]] and [[Rosalind Franklin]] that was the basis of the elucidation of the molecular structure of DNA. [[Image:Strand102.jpg|South West Building, Strand Campus, overlooking the [[Thames]]|thumb|167px|left]] During World War II King's was evacuated out of London to [[Bristol University]]. The first qualification issued by King's was the [[Associateship of King's College]], or AKC. The course, which concerns questions of ethics and theology, is still awarded today to students (and staff) who take an optional three year course alongside their standard [[academic degree|degree]]. Successful completion entitles the [[Alumnus|graduate]] to bear the letters AKC after their name. The College today is the product of mergers with a number of other institutions over the years, including [[Queen Elizabeth College]] and [[Chelsea College of Science and Technology]] in 1985, and with the [[Institute of Psychiatry]] and the [[United Medical and Dental Schools of Guy's and St Thomas' Hospitals]]. [[Florence Nightingale]]'s original training school for nurses is now incorporated as the [[Florence Nightingale School of Nursing and Midwifery]]. Today, there are nine schools of study (see below). [[King's College School]] was created as King's Junior Department at the time of the College's founding. Originally situated in the basement of the [[Strand, London|Strand]] campus, the School relocated to [[Wimbledon, London|Wimbledon]] in 1897. [[King's College School]] is no longer associated with King's College London. In 2003 the College was granted degree-awarding powers in its own right, (as opposed to through the [[University of London]]) by the [[Her Majesty's Most Honourable Privy Council|Privy Council]]. This power remained unexercised until 2007, when the College announced that all students starting courses from September 2007 onwards would be awarded degrees conferred by King's itself, rather than by the [[University of London]]. The new certificates however still make reference to the fact that King's is a constituent college of the [[University of London]].{{cite web |url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/content/1/c6/02/89/68/WEBDOCDAPFAQ2.doc|title=Degree Awarding Powers Frequently Asked Questions 2 August 2005 |accessdate=2006-11-20}} All current students with at least one year of study remaining were in August 2007 offered the option of choosing to be awarded a [[University of London]] [[academic degree|degree]] or a King's [[academic degree|degree]]. In 2007, for the second consecutive year, students from the [[King's College London School of Law]] won the national round of the Jessup International Law Moot Court. The Jessup [[moot court|moot]] is the biggest international mooting competition in the world. The King's team went on to represent the UK as national champions.{{cite web |url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/phpnews/wmview.php?ArtID=1746 |title=Law students repeat mooting success|accessdate=2007-04-26 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070316011127/http://www.kcl.ac.uk/phpnews/wmview.php?ArtID=1746 |archivedate = 2007-03-16}} == Campuses == === Strand campus === [[Image:Guys campus kcl 2.jpg|Guy's Campus|thumb|right|170px]] [[Image:kcl guys campus.jpg|The Colonnade, Guy's Campus|thumb|right|170px]] [[Image:Kcl chapel.jpg|The [[Listed building|Grade I]] listed College Chapel on the Strand Campus was redesigned in 1864 by [[Sir George Gilbert Scott]]|thumb|right|170px]] The Strand Campus is the founding campus of King's. Located next to [[Somerset House]] in the [[City of Westminster]], and sharing its frontage along the [[River Thames]], most of the Schools of [[King's College London School of Arts & Humanities|Arts & Humanities]], [[King's College London School of Law|Law]], Social Science & Public Policy and Physical Sciences & Engineering are housed here. The campus combines the Grade I listed King's Building of 1831 designed by [[Robert Smirke (architect)|Sir Robert Smirke]], and the Byzantine [[Gothic Architecture|Gothic]] College Chapel, redesigned in 1864 by [[Sir George Gilbert Scott]] with the more modern [[Strand, London|Strand]] Building, completed in 1972. The Chesham Building in Surrey Street was purchased after the Second World War. The Macadam Building of 1975 houses [[KCLSU]]'s activities and is named after King's alumnus [[Ivison Macadam|Sir Ivison Macadam]], first President of [[National Union of Students (United Kingdom)|NUS]]. A [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]]-protected [[Ancient Rome|Roman]] Bath is situated on the site of the Strand Campus and can be accessed via the Surrey Street entrance. Hidden by surrounding College buildings, the Baths were mentioned by [[Charles Dickens]] in chapter thirty-five of ''[[David Copperfield (novel)|David Copperfield]]''. Moreover [[Aldwych tube station]], a well-preserved but disused [[London Underground]] station, is integrated as part of the King's [[Strand, London|Strand]] campus. A Rifle Range is located on the site of a platform taken out of public service in 1917. (Nearest underground stations: [[Temple tube station|Temple]], [[Covent Garden tube station|Covent Garden]]) === Guy's campus === [[Guy's Hospital]] in the [[London Borough of Southwark]], established in 1726, houses parts of [[King's College London School of Medicine]]. The founder and benefactor of the hospital, [[Thomas Guy]], was a wealthy bookseller and a governor of [[St Thomas' Hospital]]. He lies buried in the vault beneath the 18th-century chapel at Guy's. Silk-merchant William Hunt was a later benefactor who gave money in the early nineteenth century to build Hunt's House. Today this is the site of New Hunt's House. The Henriette Raphael building, constructed in 1903, and the Gordon Museum are also located here. In addition, the Hodgkin building, Shepherd's House and Guy's chapel are prominent buildings within the campus. Guy's KCLSU centre is situated in Boland House. (Nearest underground stations: [[London Bridge tube station|London Bridge]], [[Borough tube station|Borough]]) === Waterloo campus === Across [[Waterloo Bridge]] from the Strand Campus, the Waterloo Campus near the [[South Bank Centre]] in the [[London Borough of Lambeth]] consists of the [[James Clerk Maxwell]] Building and the [[Rosalind Franklin|Franklin]]-[[Maurice Wilkins|Wilkins]] Building, which was originally constructed as His Majesty's Stationery Office. King's acquired the building in the 1980s. The James Clerk Maxwell Building houses the Principal's Office, most of the central administrative offices of the College and part of the Florence Nightingale School of Nursing & Midwifery. The Franklin-Wilkins Building is home to the School of Health & Life Sciences that includes Pharmacy, the Department of Education and to part of the School of Nursing & Midwifery. The campus is also home to the London site of [[Schiller International University]]. (Nearest underground station: [[Waterloo tube station|Waterloo]]) === St Thomas' campus === The [[St Thomas' Hospital|St Thomas' Campus]] in the [[London Borough of Lambeth]], facing the [[Palace of Westminster|Houses of Parliament]] across the Thames, houses parts of the School of Medicine and the Dental Institute. The [[Florence Nightingale Museum]] is also located here. (Nearest underground station: [[Westminster tube station|Westminster]]) === Denmark Hill campus === Further south, [[King's College Hospital]], the [[Maudsley Hospital]] and the [[Institute of Psychiatry]] form the [[Denmark Hill]] Campus, straddling the borders of the [[London Borough of Lambeth]] and the [[London Borough of Southwark]] in [[Camberwell]], the only campus not situated on the River Thames. As well as the [[Institute of Psychiatry|IoP]], parts of the Dental Institute and School of Medicine, and a large hall of residence, King's College Hall, are housed here. The KCL library for this campus is on-site, known as the Weston Education Centre (WEC). (Nearest overground station: [[Denmark Hill]]) === Refurbishment === King's is coming to the end of a decade of restorative and refurbishment projects, with investment of Â£550 million.King's College London Profile 2006 These include the Franklin-Wilkins Building at the Waterloo campus, the [[Maughan Library]] on Chancery Lane and the renovation of the chapel at the [[Strand, London|Strand]] campus at a cost of Â£750,000. The Strand Campus redevelopment won the Green Gown Award in 2007 for sustainable construction. The award recognised the âreduced energy and carbon emissions from a sustainable refurbishment of the historic South Range of the King's Building'.{{cite web |url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/phpnews/wmview.php?ArtID=1779 |title=King's wins top Green Award |work=King's College London |accessdate=2007-04-25 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070611232155/http://www.kcl.ac.uk/phpnews/wmview.php?ArtID=1779 |archivedate = 2007-06-11}} King's was also the recipient of the 2003 City Heritage Award for the conversion of the Grade II* listed [[The Maughan Library|Maughan Library]].{{cite web |url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/phpnews/wmview.php?ArtID=394 |title=King's library wins prestigious heritage award |work=King's College London |accessdate=2007-04-25 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070708040352/http://www.kcl.ac.uk/phpnews/wmview.php?ArtID=394 |archivedate = 2007-07-08}} In December 2009 it was announced that King's would acquire the East Wing of Somerset House under a 78-year lease. The wing is to accommodate a cultural centre, open to the public, and allow the relocation of the college's School of Law.King's College London (7 December 2009) [http://www.kcl.ac.uk/news/news_details.php?news_id=1244&year=2009 Kingâs and Somerset House join forces (Press Release)]. Retrieved 7 December 2009. ==Organisation and administration== ===Schools and departments=== [[Image:King's College 158.jpg|A [[Classical antiquity|Classical]] sculpture of [[Sappho]] in the King's Building, Strand Campus|thumb]] King's currently has the following nine constituent Schools of Study: * [[King's College London School of Arts and Humanities|Arts & Humanities]] * Biomedical & Health Sciences * Dental Institute * [[Institute of Psychiatry]] * [[King's College London School of Law|Law]] * [[King's College London School of Medicine|Medicine]] * Natural & Mathematical Sciences * [[Florence Nightingale School of Nursing and Midwifery|Nursing & Midwifery]] * Social Science & Public Policy The [[Department of War Studies, KCL|Department of War Studies]] is unique in the UK, and is supported by facilities such as [[Liddell Hart Centre for Military Archives|The Liddell Hart Centre for Military Archives]], the Centre for Defence Studies,{{cite web |url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/schools/sspp/ws/research/groups/cds/ |title=Centre for Defence Studies |accessdate=2006-11-20}} and the King's Centre for Military Health Research. Authorities on [[Mozart]] ([[Cliff Eisen]]), [[Verdi]] ([[Roger Parker]]) and [[Wagner]] ([[John Deathridge]]) hold professorships; as do many active composers, including [[Silvina Milstein]], [[George Benjamin (composer)|George Benjamin]] and [[Robert Keeley (composer)|Robert Keeley]]. The [[Royal Academy of Dramatic Art|Royal Academy of Dramatic Art (RADA)]] is administered through King's, and its students graduate alongside members of the departments which form the School of Arts & Humanities. As RADA does not have degree awarding powers, its courses are validated by King's.{{cite web|url=http://www.rada.org/aboutus/index.aspx?id=78&linkidentifier=id&itemid=78|title=About RADA|accessdate=2008-08-23 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080822104812/http://www.rada.org/aboutus/index.aspx?id=78&linkidentifier=id&itemid=78 |archivedate = 2008-08-22}} ===Academic year=== King's academic year runs from the last Monday in September to the first Friday in June.{{cite web|url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/about/semester.html|title=Term dates|accessdate=7 October 2010|publisher=Kingâs College London}} Graduation ceremonies are held in June or July, with ceremonies held in [[Southwark Cathedral]] for the School of Medicine and the Dental Institute and in the [[Barbican Centre]] for all other Schools.{{cite web |url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/about/structure/admin/acservices/grad/graduation-ceremonies/when/ |title=Locations|accessdate=2009-08-29}} Since 2008 King's graduates have worn gowns designed by [[Vivienne Westwood]].{{cite news |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/fashion/main.jhtml?xml=/fashion/2008/01/02/efaz102.xml |title=The Daily Telegraph: A to Z of what's hot for 2008|accessdate=2008-01-03 | location=London | first=Marion | last=Hume | date=2008-01-02}} ===Finances=== In the financial year ended 31 July 2010 King's had a total income of Â£508.05 million (2008/09 â Â£485.62 million) and total expenditure of Â£497.58 million (2008/09 â Â£484.88 million). Key sources of income included Â£151.89 million from Funding Council grants (2008/09 â Â£150.21 million), Â£144.05 million from research grants and contracts (2008/09 â Â£134.96 million), Â£118.4 million from tuition fees and education contracts (2008/09 â Â£100.48 million) and Â£6.61 million from endowment and investment income (2008/09 â Â£11.78 million). At year end King's had total endowments of Â£115.23 million and total net assets of Â£683.58 million. King's has a credit rating of AA from [[Standard & Poor's]]. ==Academics== ===Rankings=== {{Infobox UK university rankings | ARWU_N = 7 | ARWU_W = 63 | QS_N = 6 | QS_W = 27 | THE_N = 7 | THE_W = 56 | LINE_1 = 0 | Complete = 16 | The_Guardian = 30 | Sunday_Times = 17 | The_Times = 24 }} In the UK King's is consistently ranked among the top 10 British universities. Internationally, King's is consistently ranked among the top 100 universities in the world by all major [[College and university rankings#International rankings from regional organizations|global university rankings]] compilers, having been placed between 27th by the 2011 [[QS World University Rankings]]http://www.topuniversities.com/university-rankings/world-university-rankings/2011 and 56th worldwide by the [[Times Higher Education World University Rankings]].http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/world-university-rankings/2010-2011/top-200.html According to the 2009 Times Good University Guide, several subjects taught at Kingâs, including [[King's College London School of Law|Law]], History, [[Department of War Studies, KCL|War Studies]] (ranked under Politics), [[Classics]], Spanish, [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]], [[Musicology|Music]], [[Dentistry]], Medicine, [[Nursing]] and [[Food Science]] are among the top five in the country.{{cite news |url= http://extras.timesonline.co.uk/tol_gug/gooduniversityguide.php|title=The Times Good University Guide 2009|work=The Times |location=London |accessdate=2009-03-02 | first1=Sam | last1=Coates | first2=Francis | last2=Elliott | first3=Roland | last3=Watson}} {{Dead link|date=September 2011|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} According to the 2010 Complete University guide, many subjects at King's, including Classics, English, French, Geography, German, History, Music, Philosophy and Theology, rank within the Top 10 nationally. The Dental Institute has been known as the "Oxbridge Dentistry" as the University of Cambridge and the University of Oxford do not offer Dentistry as a course of study.{{Citation needed|date=October 2010}} The College has had 24 of its subject-areas awarded the highest rating of 5 or 5* for research quality, and in 2007 it received a good result in its audit by the [[Quality Assurance Agency]]. It is in the top tier for research earnings. In September 2010, the [[Sunday Times]] selected King's as the "University of the Year 2010/11" taking the position from last year's winner Oxford University.{{Citation needed|date=October 2010}} ===Medicine === {{main|King's College London School of Medicine}} [[Image:Shepherds house guys campus kcl.JPG|Shepherd's House, Guy's Campus|thumb|left|170px]] King's is the largest centre for healthcare education in Europe.{{cite web|url=http://www.kingshealthpartners.org/khp/key-facts/viewing/10008|title=Key Facts|accessdate=7 October 2010|publisher=Kingâs Health Partners}} King's College London School of Medicine has over 2,000 undergraduate students, over 1,400 teachers, four main teaching hospitals â [[Guy's Hospital]], [[King's College Hospital]], [[St Thomas' Hospital]] and [[University Hospital Lewisham]] â and 17 associated district general hospitals.{{cite web|url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/schools/medicine/about/meded/|title=Division of Medical Education|accessdate=7 October 2010|publisher=Kingâs College London}} Kingâs College London Dental Institute is the largest dental school in Europe.{{Cite news |work=The Independent |location=London | title = Put a smile back on your face| accessdate =7 September 2010| url =http://www.independent.co.uk/news/education/higher/put-a-smile-back-on-your-face-554765.html| date =29 July 2004 }} The Florence Nightingale School of Nursing & Midwifery is the oldest professional school of nursing in the world.{{cite web|url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/schools/nursing/about/|title=Nursing & Midwifery â About us|accessdate=7 October 2010|publisher=Kingâs College London}} King's is a major centre for biomedical research. It is a founding member of [[King's Health Partners]], one of the largest [[academic health sciences centre]]s in Europe with a turnover of over Â£2 billion and approximately 25,000 employees. It also is home to six [[Medical Research Council (UK)#Institutes, Centres and Units|Medical Research Council centres]], the most of any British university,{{cite web|url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/research/mrc.html|title=Medical Research Council centres|accessdate=7 October 2010|publisher=Kingâs College London}} and is part of two of the twelve biomedical research centres established by the NHS in England â the Guy's & St Thomas'/King's College London Comprehensive Biomedical Research Centre and the South London and Maudsley/KCL Institute of Psychiatry Biomedical Research Centre.{{cite web|url=http://www.nihr.ac.uk/infrastructure/Pages/infrastructure_biomedical_research_centres.aspx|title=Biomedical Research Centres |accessdate=7 October 2010|publisher=National Institute for Health Research}} King's Drug Control Centre currently holds the official UK contract for running [[doping (sport)|doping]] tests on UK athletes, and will likely continue to do so for the [[2012 Olympics]], to be held in London.{{cite web|url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/schools/biohealth/research/drugcontrol/|title=Drug Control Centre|accessdate=7 October 2010|publisher=Kingâs College London}} ===Admissions === The ''[[Sunday Times]]'' has ranked King's as the 6th most difficult UK university to gain admission to.{{cite news |url=http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/University_Guide/article236892.ece |title=The UCAS points system |work=The Sunday Times University Guide 2005 |accessdate=2006-11-20 | location=London | first1=Sam | last1=Coates | first2=Francis | last2=Elliott | first3=Roland | last3=Watson}} According to the 2008 Times Good University Guide approximately 30% of King's undergraduates come from independent schools.{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/education/good_university_guide/article2166532.ece|title=The Times Good University Guide 2008 â King's College London|accessdate=2008-11-24}} At the undergraduate level admission to King's is extremely competitive. In 2011 some courses, such as English, Law and Business Management, had 15 or more applicants per place or an acceptance rate of less than 7.5 percent.{{cite web|url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/study/ug/download/index.aspx|work=KCL Prospectus 2011|title=King's College London Undergraduate Prospectus 2011|publisher=King's College London|accessdate=2011-07-03}} ===Libraries=== King's library facilities are spread across its five campuses; the College's estate also includes the library at [[Bethlem Royal Hospital]] in the [[London Borough of Bromley]].[http://www.kcl.ac.uk/library Official Site: Library Services] The collections encompass over one million printed books, as well as thousands of journals and electronic resources. ====The Maughan Library==== [[Image:Kclssa.jpg|[[The Maughan Library]] as viewed from [[Chancery Lane]]|thumb|right|170px]] [[The Maughan Library]] is housed in the [[Listed building|Grade II* listed]] 19th century [[Gothic Revival architecture|gothic]] former [[Public Record Office]] building situated on [[Chancery Lane]] near the Strand Campus. The building was designed by [[James Pennethorne|Sir James Pennethorne]] and is home to the books and [[Academic journal|journals]] of the School's of Humanities, [[King's College London School of Law|Law]], Physical Sciences & Engineering, and Social Science & Public Policy. It also houses the Special Collections and rare books. Inside the Library is the octagonal Round Reading Room, inspired by the reading room of the [[British Museum]], and the former Rolls Chapel (renamed the Weston Room following a donation from the [[Garfield Weston Foundation]]) with its [[stained glass window]]s, [[mosaic]] floor and monuments, including an important [[Renaissance]] terracotta figure by [[Pietro Torrigiano]] of Dr Yonge, Master of the Rolls, who died in 1516. ====Other libraries==== *The '''Foyle Special Collections Library''' at [[Chancery Lane]] houses a collection of over 150,000 printed works as well as thousands of [[map]]s, slides, sound recordings and some [[manuscript]] material.{{cite web|url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/iss/archivespec/collections/sc/|title=Special Collections|accessdate=2009-07-01}} *The '''Tony Arnold Library''' at [[Chancery Lane]] houses a collection of over 3000 law books and 140 law journals. It was named after Tony Arnold, the longest serving Secretary of the [[Institute of Taxation]]. In September 2001 the library became part of the law collection of Kings College London.{{cite web|url=http://www.tax.org.uk/showarticle.pl?id=3951;n=3621 |title=CIOT â Using the Library |publisher=Tax.org.uk |date=1997-12-18 |accessdate=2010-04-29 |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20060930234116/http://www.tax.org.uk/showarticle.pl?id=3951;n=3621 |archivedate=2006-09-30}} *The '''Franklin-Wilkins Library''' at the Waterloo Campus is home to extensive management and education holdings, as well as wide-ranging biomedical, health and life sciences coverage includes nursing, midwifery, public health, pharmacy, biological and environmental sciences, biochemistry and forensic science.[http://www.kcl.ac.uk/library/libraries/waterloo.aspx Franklin Wilkins Library] *The '''New Hunt's House Library''' at Guy's Campus covers all aspects of biomedical science. There are also extensive resources for medicine, dentistry, physiotherapy and health services.[http://www.kcl.ac.uk/library/libraries/guys.aspx New Hunt's House Library] *The '''Weston Education Centre Library''' at the Denmark Hill Campus has particular strengths in the areas of [[gastroenterology]], liver disease, diabetes, obstetrics, gynaecology, paediatrics and the [[history of medicine]].[http://www.kcl.ac.uk/library/libraries/denmarkhill.aspx Weston Education Centre] *The '''St Thomas' House Library''' holdings cover all aspects of basic medical sciences, clinical medicine and health services research.[http://www.kcl.ac.uk/library/libraries/stthomas.aspx St Thomas' House Library] *The '''Institute of Psychiatry (IoP) Library''' is the largest psychiatric library in Western Europe, holding 3,000 print journal titles, 550 of which are current subscriptions, as well as access to over 3,500 electronic journals, 38,000 books, and training materials.{{cite web|url=http://www.iop.kcl.ac.uk/departments/?locator=12 |title=IoP: Library |publisher=Iop.kcl.ac.uk |accessdate=2010-04-29}} *The '''Bethlem Royal Hospital Library''' contains a smaller collection to support students and staff working at the hospital.[http://www.kcl.ac.uk/iss/visitors/library/bethlem.html Bethlem Library] ==Student life== ===Students' Union=== {{main|King's College London Students' Union}} [[Image:Kclsu logo new.gif|KCLSU logo|thumb|right|170px]] [[Image:reggiethelion.jpg|Reggie the Lion|thumb|right|170px]] [[King's College London Students' Union]] ([[KCLSU]]) is the oldest student union in London, founded just before [[University College London Union]], and provides a good range of activities and services: over 50 sports clubs (including the Boat Club which rows on the [[River Thames]] and the Rifle Club which uses the College's shooting range located at the disused [[Aldwych tube station]] beneath the Strand Campus), 60 societies, a wide range of volunteering opportunities, 2 bars, 2 nightclubs, shops, eating places and a gym. A former President of KCLSU, [[Sir Ivison Macadam]] (after whom the Students' Union building on the Strand Campus has since been named) went on to be elected as the first President of the [[National Union of Students (United Kingdom)|National Union of Students]], and KCLSU has played an active role there and in the [[University of London Union]] ever since. ''Roar'' is KCLSU's monthly magazine. It carries stories, reviews and features on a range of topics, reporting on Students' Union events, campaigns, clubs and societies, as well as coverage of the arts, books and fashion. ''King's Bench'', has grown from strength to strength, challenging the dominance ''Roar'' once had in the media spectrum.King's Bench website, www.kbkcl.co.uk/team It is published tri-annually and welcomes contributions from all of King's students, either for publication in its printed edition, or on its [http://www.kbkcl.co.uk website]. The College itself also publishes a range of periodicals reporting on various aspects of King's.{{cite web|url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/media/publications/index.html |title=Publications |publisher=Kcl.ac.uk |date=2010-03-22 |accessdate=2010-04-29}} In the 1970s, the King's mascot, "[[King's College London Students' Union#Mascot|Reggie]]", was buried upside-down in a pit near [[Waterloo Station]], which was filled with concrete; only the tip of his tail remained visible. Later, he was lost for many years in the 1990s, and not recovered until he was found in a field. Having been restored at the cost of around Â£15,000, Reggie has been placed on display in the KCLSU Student Centre at the Strand Campus. Protected in a glass case, he is filled with concrete to prevent theft, particularly by [[University College London|UCL]] students who, prior to his burial and dumping, had also castrated him. (King's students had also stolen one UCL mascot, Phineas and, in an apocryphal legend, allegedly played football with the head of [[Jeremy Bentham|Jeremy Bentham's]] Auto-icon). There are three "Reggies" in existence: the original, on display in [[KCLSU]]'s Student Centre at the Strand Campus, a [[papier-mÃ¢chÃ©]] Reggie outside the Great Hall at the Strand Campus (pictured above), and a small [[sterling silver]] incarnation displayed during Graduation ceremonies. === Competition with UCL === {{Unreferenced section|date=November 2010}} [[Image:KCLMaughanLibrary.jpg|[[The Maughan Library]]|thumb|right|170px]] {{main|Student Rags}} Competition within the [[University of London]] is most intense between King's and [[University College London]], the two oldest institutions. In the early twentieth century, rivalry was centred on their respective [[mascot]]s. University College's was Phineas Maclino, a wooden [[tobacconist|tobacconist's]] sign of a kilted Jacobite [[Scottish Highlands|Highlander]] purloined from outside a shop in [[Tottenham Court Road]] during the celebrations of the relief of [[Ladysmith, KwaZulu-Natal|Ladysmith]] in 1900. King's later addition was a giant beer bottle representing "bottled youth". In 1923 it was replaced by a new mascot to rival Phineas â Reggie the Lion, who made his debut at a King's-[[University College London|UCL]] sporting [[rag]] in December 1923, protected by a lifeguard of engineering students armed with T-squares. Thereafter, Reggie formed the centrepiece of annual [[fresher]]s' processions by King's students around [[Aldwych]] in which new students were typically flour bombed. Although riots between respective College students occurred in Central London well into the 1950s, rivalry is now limited to the [[rugby union]] pitch and skulduggery over mascots, with an annual Varsity match taking place between [[King's College Rugby Club|King's College London RFC]] and University College London RFC. === Competition with LSE === Tensions between King's and the [[London School of Economics]] were ignited on 2 December 2005 when at least 200 students from [[London School of Economics|LSE]] (across the road from the Strand campus) diverted off from the annual "barrel run" and caused an estimated Â£32,000 (''[[The Beaver]]'', [[London School of Economics|LSE]], 26 September 2006) of damage to the English department at King's.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/4506664.stm |title=Students in university rampage |work=[[BBC News]] 7 December 2005 |accessdate=2006-11-20 | date=2005-12-07}} Principal [[Rick Trainor]] called for no retaliation and [[LSE Students' Union]] were forced to issue an apology as well as foot the bill for the damage repair. While [[London School of Economics|LSE]] officially condemned the action, a photograph was published in the ''[[Beaver]]'' (the LSE SU Student Newspaper) which was later picked up by the ''Times'' that showed [[London School of Economics|LSE]] Director [[Howard Davies (LSE)|Sir Howard Davies]] drinking with members of the [[LSE Students' Union]] shortly before the barrel run â and the "rampage" â began. King's appears to have been targeted, however, principally owing to its close proximity to [[London School of Economics|LSE]] rather than by any ill-feeling. There is also somewhat of a sporting rivalry between the two institutions, albeit to a lesser extent than with [[University College London|UCL]]. ===Student housing=== [[Image:kingsstatue.jpg|[[Sophocles]]: [[Classical antiquity|Classical]]sculpture in the King's Building, Strand Campus|thumb|right|170px]] King's has six halls of residence located throughout London. They are: *'''Brian Creamer House''' & '''The Rectory''' (self-catered) at [[St Thomas' Hospital|St Thomas' Campus]] *'''Wolfson House''' (self-catered) at [[Guy's Hospital|Guy's Campus]] *'''The [[Great Dover Street]] Apartments''' (self-catered) at [[Guy's Hospital|Guy's Campus]] *'''The [[Stamford Street]] Apartments''' (self catered) at the [[Waterloo Road, London|Waterloo Campus]] *'''King's College Hall''' (catered) at the [[Denmark Hill|Denmark Hill Campus]] *'''Hampstead Residence''' (self-catered) in [[Hampstead]] ==== Intercollegiate Halls of Residence==== King's also has the largest number of bedspaces in the [[University of London]] Intercollegiate Halls.{{cite web|url=http://www.lon.ac.uk/halls.html |title=University of London â Intercollegiate Halls |publisher=Lon.ac.uk |date=2010-03-26 |accessdate=2010-04-29}} The halls are: *Canterbury Hall, Commonwealth Hall, College Hall, [[Connaught Hall, London|Connaught Hall]], [[Hughes Parry Hall, London|Hughes Parry Hall]] and [[International Hall, London|International Hall]] near [[Russell Square]] in [[Bloomsbury]] *Lillian Penson Hall (postgraduates only) in [[Paddington]] *[[Nutford House, London|Nutford House]] in [[Marble Arch]] Some students are also selected to live in [[International Students House, London]]. ==People== ===Notable alumni=== {{main|List of King's College London alumni}} [[Image:Desmond tutu wef.jpg|[[Desmond Tutu]], B.D. '65, M.Th. '66|thumb|left|200px]] [[Image:Thomashardy restored.jpg|[[Thomas Hardy]]|thumb|right|114px]] The incumbent Prime Minister of Jordan, [[Marouf al-Bakhit]], graduated from King's with a PhD in [[Department of War Studies, KCL|War Studies]] in 1990,{{cite web|url=http://www.globalinsight.com/Perspective/PerspectiveDetail2538.htm|title=Biography of Marouf al-Bakhit|year=2005|accessdate=2008-12-22}} [[NapolÃ©on, Prince Imperial|Prince Eugene Louis NapolÃ©on]], the ill-fated scion of the [[House of Bonaparte|Bonaparte Dynasty]], studied physics and mathematics at King's from 1871 to 1872,Comment, Oct 2006, p. 11 http://www.kcl.ac.uk/content/1/c6/01/14/61/Comment169.pdfEdward Legge, The Empress Eugenie 1870 to 1910, p.11 (Kessinger Publishing, 2005). [[Tassos Papadopoulos]], president of [[Cyprus]] from 2003 to 2008 graduated from King's with a degree in Law in 1955,{{cite news | first=Antigone | last=Drousiotis | title=Tassos Papadopoulos â We thought we would change the World) | date=2008-02-10 | url =http://www.phileleftheros.com/main/main.asp?gid=441&id=535829 | work=[[Phileleftheros]] | accessdate = 2008-08-05 }} while his predecessor [[Glafkos Klerides]] who served as president of [[Cyprus]] from 1993 to 2003 graduated with a Law degree in 1948.{{cite web|url=http://www.mlahanas.de/Cyprus/Bios/GlafkosClerides.html|title=Glafkos Ioannou Clerides|year=2005|accessdate=2008-01-16}} [[France-Albert RenÃ©]] president of the [[Seychelles]] from 1977 to 2004 studied Law at King's,{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/?id=Mz-fXRsedPMC&pg=PA459&lpg=PA459&dq=%22france+albert%22+ren%C3%A9+king's+college+london|title=France-Albert RenÃ©=[[Google Books]]|year=2007|accessdate=2008-01-27|isbn=9781857431261|author1=East, Roger|author2=Thomas, Richard}} [[Lynden Pindling|Sir Lynden Pindling]] prime minister of the [[Bahamas]] from 1967 to 1992 graduated with a Law degree in 1952,{{cite web|url=http://www.myplp.com/pm_pindling.php|title=Sir Lynden Pindling|accessdate=2008-08-06}} [[Godfrey Binaisa]] president of [[Uganda]] from 1979 to 1980 graduated with a Law degree in 1955,{{cite book | last = Wolfgang, M. E. & Lambert, R. D. | title = Africa in Transition | publisher=American Academy of Political and Social Science | year = 1977 | page = 204}} [[Abd ar-Rahman al-Bazzaz]] prime minister of [[Iraq]] from 1965 to 1966 graduated from King's,{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/?id=6VeCWQfVNjkC&pg=PA40&dq=%22prime+minister+of%22+%22king%27s+college+london%22|title=The Oxford Dictionary of Islam â Abdul-Rahman al-Bazzaz|year=2004|accessdate=2008-12-23|isbn=9780195125597|author1=Esposito, John L}} Sir [[Lee Moore (politician)|Lee Moore]], prime minister of [[Saint Kitts and Nevis]] from 1979 to 1980, graduated with a degree in Law and Theology,{{cite web|url=http://www.cuopm.com/newsitem.asp?articlenumber=49|title=Biography of Sir Lee Moore|accessdate=2008-12-22}} and [[Sir Shridath Ramphal]], former [[Secretary General of the Commonwealth]], graduated with a Law degree in 1952.http://www.limelightmagazine.org/magazine/stories-details.asp?StoryId=194 [[Sarojini Naidu]], the first woman President of the [[Indian National Congress]] and an architect of the Indian freedom movement, also studied at King's.http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/401841/Sarojini-Naidu Notable King's alumni to have held senior positions in British and Irish politics include the British Foreign Secretary [[David Owen|David Owen, Baron Owen]], two Speakers of the House of Commons in [[Horace Maybray King, Baron Maybray-King|Horace King, Baron Maybray-King]] (English) and [[James Lowther, 1st Viscount Ullswater]], Leader of the House of Commons [[John MacGregor, Baron MacGregor of Pulham Market]] (Law, 1962), and Irish Republican & revolutionary leader [[Michael Collins (Irish Leader)|Michael Collins]]. As of the current Parliament there are 14 King's graduates in the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]], and 14 King's graduates in the [[House of Lords]]. In Law King's alumni include current Lord Justice of Appeal [[Jeremy Sullivan|Sir Jeremy Sullivan]] (Law, 1967);{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/6365057.stm |title=UK | UK Politics | Profile: Sir Jeremy Sullivan |publisher=BBC News |date=2007-02-15 |accessdate=2010-04-29}} two incumbent High Court judges, [[David Penry-Davey|Sir David Penry-Davey]] (Law, 1964){{cite news|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/iron-fist-in-a-velvet-glove-to-fight-the-bars-corner-1318974.html |title=Iron fist in a velvet glove to fight the Bar's corner â UK, News |work=The Independent |location=London |date=1996-02-14 |accessdate=2010-04-29 | first=David | last=Penry-Davey}} and [[David Foskett|Sir David Foskett]] (Law, 1970);{{cite web|url=http://www.kclbarsociety.co.uk/websitepages.php?id=5 |title=:: The Bar Society of King's College London :: |publisher=Kclbarsociety.co.uk |accessdate=2010-04-29}} current Judge of the [[International Court of Justice]], [[Abdul Koroma]] (International Law, 1976);{{cite web|url=http://www.icj-cij.org/court/?p1=1&p2=2&p3=1&judge=4 |title=Current Members | International Court of Justice |publisher=Icj-cij.org |accessdate=2010-04-29}} and the current Chief Justice of Western Australia [[Wayne Martin]] (Law, 1975). [[Image:John Keats by William Hilton.jpg|[[John Keats]]|thumb|left|114px]] [[Image:CMS Higgs-event.jpg|thumb|right|114px|The [[Higgs boson]] (here simulated) was theorised by [[Peter Higgs]]]] King's alumni in religion include the [[Nobel Peace Prize]] laureate and Archbishop Emeritus of Cape Town [[Desmond Tutu]] (Theology, 1966),{{cite web|url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/alumni/about/known/|title=King's College London â Notable Alumni|year=2006|accessdate=2008-01-16 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070829044710/http://www.kcl.ac.uk/alumni/about/known/ |archivedate = 2007-08-29}} the preceding Archbishop of Canterbury [[George Carey|George Carey, Baron Carey of Clifton]] (Theology, 1962),{{cite web|url=http://www.archbishopofcanterbury.org/919 |title=George Carey â 103rd Archbishop of Canterbury |publisher=The Archbishop of Canterbury |date=1935-11-13 |accessdate=2010-04-29}} and the current [[Chief Rabbi]] of the United Kingdom and the Commonwealth [[Jonathan Sacks|Jonathan Sacks, Baron Sacks]] (Theology & Religious Studies, 1981).{{cite web|url=http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/biography/Sacks.html |title=Rabbi Jonathan Sacks |publisher=Jewishvirtuallibrary.org |accessdate=2010-04-29}} King's is also the alma mater of the current head of The Salvation Army [[Shaw Clifton]] (Law & Theology, 1967),{{cite web|url=http://www.salvationarmy.org/ihq/www_sa.nsf/vw-sublinks/F8432C410C1F5CC78025713F005349DA?opendocument |title=General Shaw Clifton and Commissioner Helen Clifton |publisher=Salvationarmy.org |accessdate=2010-04-29}} and at least 13 current Bishops. Notable King's alumni in poetry and literature include the poet [[John Keats]] (Medicine), and the writers [[Thomas Hardy]] (French), [[Arthur C. Clarke|Sir Arthur C. Clarke]] (Mathematics & Physics), [[W. Somerset Maugham]], [[Alain de Botton]] (Philosophy), [[C.S. Forester]], [[B. S. Johnson]] (English), [[Charles Kingsley]], [[Virginia Woolf]], [[John Ruskin]], [[Radclyffe Hall]], [[Hanif Kureishi]] (Philosophy), [[Anita Brookner]] (History), [[Michael Morpurgo]] (French & English) and [[Leslie Stephen|Sir Leslie Stephen]]. In addition, the dramatist [[W. S. Gilbert|Sir W. S. Gilbert]] of Gilbert and Sullivan graduated from King's. King's alumni in the sciences include Nobel laureates [[Max Theiler]] and [[Frederick Gowland Hopkins|Sir Frederick Gowland Hopkins]];{{cite web|url=http://www.timesdaily.com/apps/pbcs.dll/section?category=NEWS&template=wiki&text=Max_Theiler|title=Max Theiler|accessdate=2008-08-06}}Joseph Needham, "Sir Frederick Gowland Hopkins, O.M., F.R.S. (1861â1947)," ''Notes and Records of the Royal Society of London'', Vol. 17, No. 2. (Dec., 1962), pp. 117â162 [http://links.jstor.org/sici?sici=0035-9149%28196212%2917%3A2%3C117%3ASFGHOF%3E2.0.CO%3B2-G] polymath [[Francis Galton|Sir Francis Galton]]; pathologist [[Thomas Hodgkin]]; pioneer of ''in vitro'' fertilization [[Patrick Steptoe]]; botanist [[David Bellamy]];{{cite web|url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/content/1/c4/37/95/profile2007.pdf|format=PDF|title=Notable Alumni=King's College London|year=2005|accessdate=2008-01-16 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070824093403/http://www.kcl.ac.uk/content/1/c4/37/95/profile2007.pdf |archivedate = 2007-08-24}} noted theoretical physicist [[Peter Higgs]] and the founder of the study of radioastronomy [[Professor EG Bowen]]. King's is also the alma mater of the founder of [[Bentley Motors]], [[W. O. Bentley|Walter Bentley]]; satirist [[Rory Bremner]] (Modern Languages, 1984);{{cite web|url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/alumni/about/known/|title=King's Notable Alumni=King's College London|year=2006|accessdate=2008-01-16 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070829044710/http://www.kcl.ac.uk/alumni/about/known/ |archivedate = 2007-08-29}} journalist [[Martin Bashir]] (Religious History, 1985);{{cite web|url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/news/news_details.php?news_id=442&year=2005|title=Martin Bashir: King's alumnus to anchor US TV news show=King's College London|year=2005|accessdate=2008-01-16}} [[Queen (band)|Queen]] bassist [[John Deacon]];{{cite web|url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/alumni/about/known/|title=King's Notable Alumni=King's College London|year=2006|accessdate=2008-01-24 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070829044710/http://www.kcl.ac.uk/alumni/about/known/ |archivedate = 2007-08-29}} and former head of the British Army [[John Harding, 1st Baron Harding of Petherton|Lord Harding]]. ====Heads of state and government==== [[Image:Francealbertrene.jpg|King's alumnus [[France-Albert RenÃ©]] (left) served at President of the Seychelles from 1977â2004|thumb|200px]] {| class="wikitable" style="float: center; border: 5px solid #BBB; margin: .96em 0 0 .9em;" |- style="font-size: 40%;"" !State !! Leader !! Office !! Reference |- |''{{flag|Bahamas}}'' |[[Lynden Pindling|Sir Lynden Pindling]] |Premier 1967â1969; Prime Minister 1969â1992 |

|- |} ===Notable faculty and staff=== ''See also [[:Category:Academics of King's College London]]'' King's has benefited from the services of academics at the top of their fields, including: image:Jamal Nazrul Islam.jpg|

 ===Nobel laureates=== {{main|List of Nobel laureates affiliated with King's College London}} There are 10 [[list of Nobel laureates|Nobel laureates]] who were either students or academics at King's.King's Nobel laureates â http://kcl.ac.uk/about/history/people/nobel.html [[Image:Mario Vargas Llosa (2010).jpg|Former Lecturer in Spanish American Literature [[Mario Vargas Llosa]], was awarded the 2010 [[Nobel Prize in Literature]]|thumb|200px]] {| class="wikitable" style="float: center; border: 5px solid #BBB; margin: .96em 0 0 .9em;" |- style="font-size: 40%;"" !Name !Prize !Year Awarded !Rationale |- |[[Charles Barkla]] |[[Nobel Prize in Physics|Physics]] |
1917
|For the discovery of X-ray fluorescence |- |[[Owen Willans Richardson|Sir Owen Richardson]] |[[Nobel Prize in Physics|Physics]] |
1928
|For pioneering the study of thermionics |- |[[Frederick Gowland Hopkins|Sir Frederick Hopkins]] |[[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine|Physiology or Medicine]] |
1929
|For research on vitamins and beriberi |- |[[Charles Scott Sherrington|Sir Charles Sherrington]] |[[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine|Physiology or Medicine]] |
1932
|For research on the nervous system |- |[[Edward Victor Appleton|Sir Edward Appleton]] |[[Nobel Prize in Physics|Physics]] |
1947
|For exploration of the ionosophere |- |[[Max Theiler]] |[[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine|Physiology or Medicine]] |
1951
|For developing a vaccine for yellow fever |- |[[Maurice Wilkins]] |[[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine|Physiology or Medicine]] |
1962
|For the discovery of the structure of DNA |- |[[Desmond Tutu]] |[[Nobel Peace Prize|Peace]] |
1984
|For his unifying role in the campaign against apartheid |- |[[James W. Black|Sir James Black]] |[[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine|Physiology or Medicine]] |
1988
|For the development of beta-blocker and anti-ulcer drugs |- |[[Mario Vargas Llosa]] |[[Nobel Prize in Literature|Literature]] |
2010
|For his trenchant images of resistance, revolt, and defeat |} ===Principals=== The Principal of King's is the chief academic and administrative officer of the College. |} ===Fellows=== ''See also [[:Category:Fellows of King's College London|Category:Fellows of King's College London]]'' == King's in fiction== *In the [[Sherlock Holmes]] story [[The Adventure of the Resident Patient]], Dr Percy Trevelyan describes himself as a "London University man" who joined King's College Hospital after graduating. *King's Department of Theology's library plays a widely fictionalized part in [[Dan Brown|Dan Brown's]] ''[[The Da Vinci Code]]''. *In [[Philip Roth]]'s novel ''[[The Professor of Desire]],'' the main character David Kepesh spent a certain period of time studying comparative literature at the College on a Fulbright Scholarship. *The Neo-Classical facade of the College, with the passage which connects the Strand to [[Somerset House]] terrace has been utilized to reproduce the late Victorian Strand in the opening scenes of [[Oliver Parker|Oliver Parker's]] 2002 film ''[[The Importance of Being Earnest (2002 film)|The Importance of Being Earnest]]''. The East Wing of the College appears, as a part of Somerset House, in a number of other productions, such as [[Wilde]], [[Flyboys]] and ''[[The Duchess]]''.{{Disambiguation needed|date=June 2011}} == See also == *[[Education in London]] *[[King's College School]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} == Further reading == * Hearnshaw, F.
